results.title: Invaders from mars
results.creator_credit: William Cameron Menzies, Edward Alperson and National Pictures
results.brief_description: After witnessing the landing of a flying saucer, a young boy finds his parents changed and alien in their behaviour. This film’s cult status is based on the art direction by director-designer Menzies who designed the sets to enhance events as seen through the boy’s eyes. A long expository dialogue-bound scene and the producer’s insistence on inserting stock footage of army manoeuvres weakened Menzies’ concept. This is the full-length version with the original ending that was cut from the version previously released in Australia. Menzies’ film was the first of the alien invaders genre to be made in colour. It was originally intended to be a 3-D release but the idea was dropped before production began.

results.title: The Next best thing
results.creator_credit: John Schlesinger, Linne Radmin, Leslie Dixon, Tom Rosenberg, Paramount Pictures and Lakeshore Entertainment
results.brief_description: Set in California,” The Next best thing” is a drama that attempts to address issues such as gay parenting and the role of alternative family units that exist outside of the dominant nuclear arrangement. Abbie (Madonna) is a yoga teacher approaching forty, frustrated by unsuccessful relationships and who feels that her opportunities for having a child are quickly diminishing. Robert (Rupert Everett) her best friend, is a gay landscape gardener who provides emotional support to Abbie on a regular basis. One night the two get drunk, sleep together, Abbie falls pregnant and after much procrastination they decide to live together and raise the child as co-parents. Complications ensue when Abbie falls for a merchant banker who wishes to move his new family to the east coast. A melodrama that at times panders to gross gay stereotypes, such as the drug loving homosexual male and materialistic queens, the film does present the notion that families in the modern age are also made up of friends and lovers, often closer and more sympathetic to individuals than their own biological family members. Features two songs from Madonna on the soundtrack and cast includes Illeana Douglas and Lynn Redgrave.

results.title: Talk 16
results.creator_credit: Adrienne Mitchell, Janis Lundman, National Film Board of Canada and Back Alley Film Productions
results.brief_description: This is a most compelling and entertaining documentary about the personal lives of five young teenage girls aged between 15 and 16. Filmed over a one-year period, Janis Lundman and Adrienne Mitchell formed quite a remarkable bond with the girls, allowing the filmmakers to present an up-close and intimate insight into each of their lives. Meet Lina, Russian born, migrated to Canada with her family when she was 5 years old, inwardly rebellious and striving to be thought of as an adult by her family - her main aim in life is to find a boyfriend; Erin is from a middle-class family, attends private school, and wants to be a model but struggles with problems of body-image; Helen of Korean-born parents who are devout Christians and hold strict family values, is an honors student caught between two cultures; Astra, a runaway teenager, is an enigma - perceptive and articulate who considers herself a problem child, hates living by the rules and enjoys living on the edge, hanging out with druggies and ex-crims; Rhonda, brash, black and ambitious skips classes but will do anything to achieve her ambition to be an actress. From different socio-economic and cultural backgrounds, together these five young girls discuss sex, drugs, boyfriends, their future, feminism, beliefs and values, body image, and family with amazing frankness and humour. An interesting concept to see the changes in each of the girls over the year of filming. Voice and narration by Janis Lundman. (Award: Florida Film Festival 1994, Grand Jury Award)

results.title: Live nude girls
results.creator_credit: Julianna Lavin, Barry Bernardi, Steve White, Steve White Properties and Republic Pictures Corporation
results.brief_description: Georgina, an attractive thirty-something, decides to hold a slumber party to celebrate the impending nuptials of her friend Jamie, a vain, B-grade actress getting married for the third time. Gathered together are several of their closest friends, all of whom have known each other since childhood. Questions of aging, parenthood, infidelity, low-self esteem, body image, bad partner choices, regrets, sexual orientation, defining childhood events, masturbation and squandered desires are workshopped over the course of the slumber party. All of the women assembled there are at transitional stages in their life, questioning the choices they have made: Georgina doubts her relationship with her female live-in lover, the perennially depressed Chris; Marcy is attempting to shake off a former lover who has taken to stalking her; Jill is pregnant with her second child. The many verbal exchanges reveal the petty jealousies that exist within the group, especially the rivalry between the straight-laced Rachel and her wilder and less inhibited sister, Jill. The friends discuss sex at great length, disclosing their fantasies, inhibitions, desires and sexual history. “Live nude girls” is a comedy that explores the territory of female sexuality, explicitly displaying the women’s numerous erotic fantasises and sexual experiences.

results.title: Vampire lovers
results.creator_credit: Roy Baker, Michael Style, Harry Fine, American International Pictures (AIP) and Hammer Films
results.brief_description: In 18th century Styria, Austria, a series of mysterious deaths causes superstitious villagers to suspect vampires abound. Meanwhile General Spielsdorf (Peter Cushing) is hosting a ball when a mysterious young woman Marcilla (Ingrid Pitt) arrives and subsequently becomes a guest at his home. Marcilla seduces the general’s beautiful young daughter, who dies after being beset by nightmares. Shortly after Marcilla turns up in several other estates (under various names) seeking out nubile young women to satiate her thirst for blood. The General and Baron Hartog gather a posse of men, to ferret out and exterminate the vampire. This version of J. Sheridan Le Fanu’s story “Carmilla” plays out as a mildly terrifying erotic thriller, produced by Hammer, the classic British production house, at a time when they were tapping into the zeitgeist of the times by presenting excessive nudity within the auspices of the horror genre. At times the film is genuinely spooky, but much of the film is lavishly devoted to displaying milky white bosoms heaving out of trussed up dresses. This film is part of a trilogy of Hammer lesbian/vampire films that incudes “Lust for a vampire” (1971) and “Twins of evil” (1972).

results.title: Apartment zero
results.brief_description: When lonely, uptight cinema owner and film buff Adrian (Colin Firth) advertises for a lodger to share his opulent Buenos Aires apartment, he attracts Jack (Ed Bochner), a suave easy-going American. Before long Adrian is seduced by Jack’s charm and becomes infatuated with him, suffering fits of jealously when Jack befriends the eccentric tenants of neighbouring apartments whom Adrian reviles. Meanwhile, a brutal serial murderer is terrorising the city, the style of the killings suggesting the killer may have been part of the death squad at the service of the former regime. While Adrian and Jack are polar opposites of each other, either one could potentially be the murderer. Like his institutionalised mother, Adrian is psychologically unstable while Jack is concealing a dubious past. Suspense builds to an unexpected climax as the killer’s identity becomes clear. Overly ambitious in its scope the film nevertheless succeeds in creating a brooding homoerotic tension between the two men which is ultimately realised through violence rather than sexual gratification.

results.title: Windows
results.creator_credit: Gordon Willis, Mike Lobell and United Artists Corporation
results.brief_description: This psycho-thriller with sexual overtones is the only directorial effort by acclaimed cinematographer Gordon Willis, who photographed many of Woody Allen’s films. Emily (Talia Shire) is a painfully introverted woman whose confidence has been further shattered by a rape attack. Her neighbour Andrea (Elizabeth Ashley), is a lesbian with a murderous past who harbours an obsessive attraction for Emily. With a highly homophobic script that provides no logic or motivation for the character’s actions, only the camerawork (by Willis) and score (by Ennio Morricone) redeem the film.

results.title: Sister my sister
results.creator_credit: Nancy Meckler, Norma Heyman, Channel 4 and NFH Productions
results.brief_description: Based on a murder case which occurred in 1934 in a provincial French village, this psychological drama is set almost wholly within the claustrophobic confines of a bourgeois household. Two sisters are employed as maids for a prudish, arrogant, middle-aged widow and the frumpy grown daughter she clings to for companionship. Immaculately groomed and discreet, the sisters slave endlessly without complaint for years to meet the perfectionist standards of the mistress of the house. Seeking any relief from this cold, oppressive environment, the sisters, who are also bound to one another in an unhealthy co-dependent relationship, eventually become lovers. As their relationship becomes increasingly tortured, the burden of meeting their employer’s expectations strains class tensions to breaking point. Beginning with the scene of the horrific murder that almost inevitably occurs, the film then effectively builds the pressure cooker atmosphere of class division, sexual repression and co-dependence that provided fertile ground for this seemingly incomprehensible crime. Cast: Julie Waters, Joely Richardson, Jodhi May, Sophie Thursfield.

results.title: Unzipped
results.creator_credit: Douglas Keeve, Michael Alden and Hachette Fillpacchi Productions
results.brief_description: Isaac Mizrahi is a talented New York fashion designer, who, after receiving negative reviews for his 1994 Spring collection, is in need of a successful season. This documentary tracks the evolution of Mizrahi’s next collection - from fledging moments of inspiration to final parade. “Unzipped” is a frank examination of the fashion industry at work - the superficiality, demands, personalities, exhaustion, frustrations, setbacks, camaraderie and creativity of it all. Supermodels take centre stage and the precociousness of this elite group is in evident abundance. Mizrahi seeks guidance from a diverse range of sources (including a ouija board) as he aims to evoke the look and style of an Inuit, mixed with 1950s cheesecake aesthetic, meets Mary Tyler Moore. Mizrahi’s mother is interviewed and gives insights into her son’s precocious talent, recognised and nurtured by her. Directed by Douglas Keeve, “Unzipped” is a candid examination of the sparks that fly when creative urges seek to ally financial interest. Features appearances from Naomi Campbell, Linda Evangelista, Cindy Crawford, Helena Christensen, Richard Gere, Eartha Kitt, Sandra Bernhard and Kate Moss. Winner of the Audience Award at the 1995 Sundance Film Festival.

Mizrahi seeks guidance from a diverse range of sources (including a ouija board) as he aims to evoke the look and style of an Inuit, mixed with 1950s cheesecake aesthetic, meets Mary Tyler Moore. Mizrahi’s mother is interviewed and gives insights into her son’s precocious talent, recognised and nurtured by her. Directed by Douglas Keeve, “Unzipped” is a candid examination of the sparks that fly when creative urges seek to ally financial interest. Features appearances from Naomi Campbell, Linda Evangelista, Cindy Crawford, Helena Christensen, Richard Gere, Eartha Kitt, Sandra Bernhard and Kate Moss. Winner of the Audience Award at the 1995 Sundance Film Festival.

results.title: Flawless
results.creator_credit: Joel Schumacher, Jane Rosenthal and Metro-Goldwyn-Mayer
results.brief_description: Gruff, homophobic, retired security guard Walt Koontz (Robert De Niro) has, what he considers to be, the unlucky fortune of living opposite flamboyant drag queen Rusty Zimmerman (Philip Seymour Hoffman). However, after suffering a debilitating stroke in a fatality involving Rusty’s friend Amber, a tenuous link is formed between them. On advice from his physical therapist Walt asks Rusty for singing lessons to improve his speech - the constant taunting between them also helps the vocal chords. They slowly become involved in one another’s personal lives, if only playing out who faces the worst adversity and trotting off predictable homophobic and heterophobic comments. The subplot involving the retrieval of the stolen money that Amber lost her life for provides the film’s climax which is littered throughout with the usual tenets one expects from Joel Schumacher (slow-mo, image distortion), with a passing nod to “As good as it gets” in its intolerable male come good scenario, and a touch of humour. Cast also includes: Barry Miller, Daphne Rubin-Vega, Wanda de Jesus.
